config.heading: The twists and turns of Australia's asylum seeker policy
config.credits: Timeline: Andrew Brooks, Michael Bachelard -

data.body: The Howard government refuses permission for the Norwegian freighter MV Tampa, carrying 433 rescued refugees, entry into Australian waters.
Australia introduces the Pacific Solution, involving agreements with Nauru and Manus Island to take asylum seekers, and boats turned back to Indonesia.
The Howard government claims asylum seekers on board the intercepted SIEV 4 threw their children overboardto secure rescue and passage to Australia, and the SIEV X sinks killing 353 people.
John Howard wins the 2001 election
Report into the children overboard affair finds former defence minister Peter Reith knew asylum-seekers did not throw children into the sea.
Four Afghani refugees sew their lips together on Nauru as part of a wider hunger strike to protest the Pacific Solution.
Mohammed Sagar is the only person left in the Nauru detention facility.
The Rudd government wins power and pledges to end offshore processing.
Rudd government pledges a “firm but fair” policy towards asylum seekers.
The Pacific Solution formally ends.
Boat Arrivals increase, placing significant pressure on immigration detention facilities.
Julia Gillard overthrows Rudd as Prime Minister
The Gillard government announces plans for an asylum-seeker processing centre in East Timor.
The transfer of minors and families from immigration detention into community-based detention begins.
The High Court rules asylum seekers can access Australian courts for judicial review, regardless of place or means of arrival.
Julia Gillard announces a deal under which Malaysia would take 800 asylum seekers in exchange for Australia taking 4000 people already assessed in Malaysia. The Abbott opposition opposes the deal.
The Gillard government agrees with recommendations of an expert panel to reopen Nauru and Manus Island detention centres to deter new arrivals
The first transfers of asylum seekers to Nauru.
The first transfers of asylum seekers to Manus Island.
Kevin Rudd overthrows Julia Gillard as Prime Minister.
Kevin Rudd announces asylum seekers arriving on unauthorised boats will never be settled in Australia. Boats keep arriving.
The Abbott government wins power, announces Operation Sovereign Borders.
The Abbott government's boat turn-back policy begins.
A riot at Manus Island, and invasion from outside, results in the killing of iranian asylum seeker Reza Barati
The Abbott government announces its refugee resettlement deal with Cambodia.
Hamid Khazaei dies in Brisbane after transfer from Manus Island, a coroner finding the death was the result of compounding errors in offshore health care.
A boat carrying 65 people bound for New Zealand is turned back, and the crew were paid thousands of dollars by Australian officials.
Malcolm Turnbull overthrows Tony Abbott.
PNG Supreme Court rules detention of asylum seekers in Manus Island is unconstitutional.
A spate of suicides among asylum seekers on Nauru
Malcolm Turnbull narrowly wins Federal election
People swap' agreement between Turnbull and Barack Obama for the US to take refugees from Nauru and Manus in exchange for Central American refugees coming to Australia.
Confirmation of US resettlement deal after an awkward conversation between Donald Trump and Malcolm Turnbull.
Confirmation that 494 people transferred from Nauru or Manus for medical care between 2012 and 2017.
Scott Morrison overthrows Malcolm Turnbul as Prime Minister
Christmas Island detention centre closes.
The Medivac bill passes both houses of parliament, the first time a government has lost a significant vote in the House of Representatives in decades.
